vectorData.altText: 17. A _____ nerve contains both sensory and motor fibres.
That's right! A mixed nerve contains both sensory and motor fibres, therefore when lesioned it can cause both motor and sensory deficits.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

Nerves of the upper limb serve three broad purposes: i) they control skeletal muscles (somatic motor fibres) so as to allow us to position and manipulate our hands, ii) they provide sensory feedback to the CNS (somatic sensory fibres) which, in turn, inform our movements, amongst other functions, and iii) they control vascular resistance and sweating, and therefore the distribution of blood to skeletal muscle and skin as well as body temperature (sympathetic postganglionic fibres). 
Because these nerves contain both motor and sensory fibres, they are called mixed nerves.
The peripheral nerves of the upper limb are derived from the brachial plexus, which is itself formed from the ventral rami of five spinal nerves, C5 - T1. The brachial plexus forms in the neck and passes behind the clavicle into the axilla. 
The blood supply to the upper limb is derived from the subclavian artery, which emerges from the thoracic outlet (superior thoracic aperture) to enter the axilla, where its name changes to the axillary artery. Venous blood drains away from the upper limb via the axillary vein, which becomes the subclavian vein and then enters the thorax via the thoracic outlet.
